Jacqueline Moffett
Homes for Black Children
1906 25th Street
Detroit, MI 48216-1440
RE: License#: CB820201177
Dear Ms. Moffett:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 9/12/2023. An exit conference was conducted with the agency on 9/18/2023 related
to the inspection findings. Since that time, addtional information was provided to the
department and it has been reviewed/assessed. Due to the violations of applicable
licensing rules with respect to the inspection, and a continued lack of demonstrated
financial stablity, the issuance of a second provisional license is recommended. A written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, further disciplinary action may
result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for the
following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
Two of three new employee records reviewed did not show documentation of three
references before the employee’s date of hire:
• One record showed one of the employee’s three references, dated 9/6/2022 was
obtained after the employee’s 8/22/2022 date of hire.
• The second record showed the employee was a rehire from 2013; and the record
did not show documentation of references.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(i) The Michigan state police, tribal police, or the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial law enforcement
agency where the person usually resides

Two of three new employee records reviewed showed the respective employee’s
ICHAT was completed on 1/10/2023 and 9/1/2023, which was after the respective
employee’s 8/22/2022 and 4/10/2023 date of hire.
Repeat Violation- Cited in the agency’s January 2022 Renewal with a corrective
action plan approved on 1/32/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any
state where the person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
One of three new employee records reviewed showed the employee had resided in
Florida within five years of her 8/22/2022 date of hire and a central registry clearance
from that state was not completed.
Repeat Violation- Cited in the agency’s January 2022 Renewal, with a
corrective action plan approved on 1/31/2022; and in the agency’s March 2021
Interim, with a corrective action plan approved on 4/8/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household must have
training in an maintain a current certification in first aid
and cardiopulmonary resuscitation from the American
Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
In one of five open foster home records reviewed, the record did not show
documentation of current first aid and CPR training for the foster home, which was
due by 7/5/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency, the borrowing agency shall have a record
containing all the following:

(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the agency.
One of one borrowed home records reviewed did not show documentation that the
family had received timely orientation to the policies of the agency. The record
showed a review of some policies on 8/26/2022, a month after the child’s 7/26/2022
d ate of placement.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency, the borrowing agency shall have a record
containing all the following:
(g) A copy of the foster parent/agency agreement signed
by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
One of one borrowed home records reviewed showed the foster parent/agency
agreement was signed by the foster parent, and agency on 8/26/2022, a month after
the child’s 7/26/2022 date of placement.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days
of its completion.
Four of eight special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation that the
special evaluation was provided to the family within 10 days of its respective
completion date. Two other special evaluations were delayed due to Child Welfare
License Module (CWLM) issues.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that the foster
parent has a right to have his or her written response
included as an attachment to the report required by
subrule (5) of this rule.
Six of eight special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation of (b) as
required by the rule.

CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services
worker that has children placed in the home.
Five of eight special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation of (c) as
required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social services workers who
have children placed in the home must be notified there is
a corrective action plan and what is required of the foster
parent in that plan.
Three of eight special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation of (7) as
required by the rule.
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of
conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
department, bureau of fire services, or local
authorities; records; report; forms; confidentiality;
disclosure of information; availability of confidential
records; child information cards to be provided to
department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
investigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care and
shall report to the department, when requested, the facts
the department requires with reference to the children
upon forms furnished by the department. Except as
otherwise provided in this subsection and subsection (4),
records regarding children and facts compiled about
children and their parents and relatives are confidential
and disclosure of this information shall be properly
safeguarded by the child care organization, the
department, and any other entity in possession of the
information. Records that are confidential under this
section are available to both of the following:

In two of eight special evaluations reviewed, Maltreatment in Care (MIC) language
was stated in the report, denoting child protective service involvement. In one report,
the agency worker referred to the department worker, as the MIC worker, and named
that person.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up
to the time of the change in placement and the needs that
remain to be met.
One of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (a)
as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Cited in the agency’s January 2022 Renewal, with a
corrective action plan approved on 1/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (b)
as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Cited in the agency’s January 2022 Renewal, with a
corrective action plan approved on 1/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(a) Two of three initial service plans were one day late respectively.

Repeat Violation- Cited in the agency’s March 2021 Interim, with a corrective
action plan approved on 4/8/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(b) One of 15 updated service plans reviewed was late by one day per the rule.
Repeat Violation- Cited in the agency’s January 2022 Renewal, with a corrective
action plan approved on 1/31/2022; and cited in the agency’s March 2021 Interim,
with a corrective action plan approved on 4/8/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plan.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in
R400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
One of six open foster child records reviewed, did not show documentation of (c); the
information was not completed.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plan.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in
R400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(h) The child behavior support plan to be used by the
foster parent.
One of six open foster child records reviewed, did not show documentation of (h), as
required by the rule.

CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.
One of three adoptive family evaluations reviewed showed the family was provided a
copy the adoptive evaluation on 8/27/2023, over a month after the adoptive
evaluation’s 7/6/2023 completion date.
Repeat Violation- Cited in the agency’s January 2022 Renewal, with a
corrective action plan approved on 1/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12203 Financial stability.
(1) An agency shall demonstrate sufficient financing, on
an ogoing basis, to ensure the agency is carrying out
its programs and meeting the requirements for
licensing .
Based on the agency’s 2023 projected operational budget that showed a $194.00 in
excess revenue, after costs and expenses, as well as its 2022 independent financial
audit which showed an end of the year deficit of $1,432,493; the agency continues to
have financial instability. The 2022 independent financial audit indicated the stated
deficit amount and noted factors indicated raise substantial doubt about the agency’s
ability to continue as a going concern.
Repeat Violation Cited in Special investigation 2022C0420008; with a
correction action plan approved in April 2023.
SRM 200 Fingerprints.
All personnel, contractors, vendors, and external auditors
who have access to CW-CHRI are required to complete
Security Awareness Training (SAT). Training is available
on the Learning Management System (LMS) for MDHHS
personnel and contractors with access to LMS. Non-
contracted agencies will complete Fingerprint Security
Awareness Training via the MDHHS public licensing
website. SAT is required to be taken within six months of
working in a position with CW-CHRI access and every two
years thereafter.

Four of six employee records reviewed of employees reported to have CHRI access
did not show compliance related to required training:
• One employee’s record did not show updated fingerprint training after 3/3/3021.
• A second record showed the employee’s updated fingerprint training was due by
3/4/2023 and was completed late on 4/27/2023.
• A third record showed the employee’s updated training was due by 3/3/2023 and was
completed late on 5/11/2023.
• A four record showed the employee’s updated fingerprint training was due by 3/3/2023
and was completed late on 8/31/2023.
FOM 722-8D Treatment plans
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Parents who are a member of a participating household.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the report
date.
Two of 18 service plans reviewed (related to two of six open foster child records
reviewed) did not show compliance:
One child's:
• 4/25/2023-7/23/2023 treatment plan did not show documentation of the birth father’s
signature until 9/6/2023.
A second child's:
• 3/3/202023- 4/1/2023 treatment plan was signed by the birth parent but not dated. It
could not be discerned if the signature was obtained timely as required by the
standard.
Repeat Violation- Cited in the agency’s January 2022 Renewal under ISEP 6:33,
with a corrective action plan approved on 1/31/2022.
FOM 801-3 Medical passport.
Initial medical passport:
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the child's
placement date to the following.

One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation the
caregiver was provider a copy of the medical passport in the time frame as required
by the standard.
Repeat Violation- Cited in the agency’s January 2022 Renewal under ISEP 6:49,
with a corrective action plan approved on 1/31/2022.
ADM 300 Child adoption assessment and adoption addendum.
Child Adoption Assessment Timeframes:
The DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be
completed by the adoption worker and approved by the
adoption supervisor within 45 calendar days of case
acceptance.
Child adoption assessment addendum.
The DHS-606, Child Adoption Assessment Addendum,
must be used to update the DHS-1927, Child Adoption
Assessment, on an annual basis if the child has not been
placed for adoption.
One of four closed child adoption records reviewed, and two of three open child
adoption records reviewed, did not show compliance:
• One child's child adoption assessment was due by 2/28/2022 and was completed 10
days late on 3/10/2022.
• A second child's child adoption assessment addendum was due by 1/10/2023 and
was completed late on 3/20/2023.
• A third child’s child adoption assessment was due by 5/25/2023 and was completed
late on 6/13/2023.
Repeat Violation Cited in the agency’s January 2022 Renewal, with a corrective
action plan approved on 1/31/2022.
ADM 330 Quarterly progress report.
Quarterly progress reports (DHHA-614) are to be completed
each quarter.
Two of four closed adoption records reviewed, and one of three open adoption
records reviewed (related to six of 22 quarterly progress reports reviewed) did not
show compliance:

• One child's 2/9/2022-5/10/2022 and 5/10/2022- 8/7/2022 quarterly progress report
was not documented.
• A second child’s 10/11/2022-1/9/2023 quarterly progress report was completed late
on 3/27/2023. This child’s 4/11/2023- 7/10/2023 quarterly progress report was
completed late on 8/8/2023.
• A third child's record did not show documentation of a 2/17/2022 quarterly progress
report. Nor a 2/18/2022-5/19/2022, or 5/20/2022-7/8/2022 quarterly progress report.
Repeat Violation Cited in the agency’s January 2022 Renewal, with a corrective
action plan approved on 1/31/2022.
ADM 980 Closing Documentation.
Adoption Closing Summary
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14
calendar days of the adoption finalization date to the
foster care worker and the Department of Health and
Services (DHHS) adoption monitor for purchase of
service cases for inclusion in the child’s permanent
record.
Three of four finalized adoption records reviewed did not show compliance:
• In two records the child’s closing summary (DHS 222) was completed 9/19/2022 and
8/3/2023, more than 14 days after the child’s respective 6/29/2022 and 10/25/2022
finalization date.
• A third’s child’s record did not show documentation of A DHS-222 for the child’s
adoption which was finalized 10/7/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12209(1)(a) Orientation and training
The agency was apprised it must clearly and consistently show documentation of
the employee’s 16 hours of orientation and that the training indicates all required
training requirements.
R400.12326 Borrowed home:
The agency was apprised it must consistently show in a two-parent license home
that both parents signed all acceptance forms.

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
ADM Closing Documentation
The agency was advised if the court delays submission of the child’s final order
of adoption to the agency, and that delay impacts the agency’s ability to timely
complete the DHS-222, documenting that barrier within the body of the DHS-222
may aid it in showing compliance to the standard.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were two incidents of substantiated maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The first incident related to a 9/14/2022 foster home complaint alleging the children
are denied meals; the foster children are told by the foster parent she has to be nice
to them to receive her money; a foster child’s mattress was placed on the floor;
another child is body shamed for body order/not using deodorant; and the children
are physically disciplined with a stick or wooden spoon. During the course of the
investigation the foster mother admitted to hitting one child hard with a belt for
urinating in the sink; and the children reported being physically disciplined.
Additionally, the evidence showed the foster mother’s daughter had threatened to
hit one of the foster children with a wooden spoon; and the children had been
denied meals on occasion. The foster home was found in willful substantial
noncompliance of the foster home behavior management rule, foster home
applicant qualification rules, and food and nutrition rule. The children were replaced
from the foster home; and revocation of the foster home’s license was
recommended by the agency.
The second incident related to a 1/11/2023 foster home complaint alleging sexual
maltreatment by one of the foster parents. The foster home was found in willful
substantial noncompliance of the licensed foster home applicant qualification rules.
The children were replaced from the home; and revocation of the foster home’s
license was recommended by the agency.
Due to CWLM issues the routing and completion of both of these special
investigation reports in the system was stalled, the respective special evaluation
report was finished/approved outside the system. The agency’s handling of these
special investigations appeared appropriate. The agency adhered to all
departmental standard except R400.12327(6)(b)(c) for both special evaluations, and
ACT 116-722.120(3) related to the former incident, each of which is cited in this
Inspection report.

There were two incidents of corporal discipline during this licensing period.
The first incident related to a 4/19/2022 foster home complaint alleging the foster
father whupped/spanked a foster child. During the course of the investigation the
foster children acknowledged being physically disciplined with an orange
object/shoehorn; and the foster parent admitted to using physical discipline. The
foster home was found in violation of the foster home behavior management rule. A
corrective action plan was developed with the foster parent. The corrective action
plan involved a safety plan, re-review of the agency’s discipline policy and foster
parent /agency agreement, and agreement by the foster parent to adhere to all of
these.
The second incident related to a 6/14/2022 foster home complaint alleging the
foster daughter was slapped by the foster father; that the foster father was upset
with the child and grabbed a belt and hit the child with it. During the course of the
investigation the child and the foster father admitted the foster father lightly popped
the child on the arm. The foster father reported doing so and advising the child to
return to her room. The agency found the foster home in violation of the foster
home behavior management rule, and a corrective action plan was developed with
the foster parent. The corrective action involved training, a re-review of the
agency’s’ discipline policy and foster parent /agency agreement and agreement by
the foster parent to adhere to all of these.
The agency handling of these special investigations appeared appropriate. The
agency adhered all departmental standards except R400.12327(6)(a)(b)(c);
R400.12327(7) for both special evaluations, and ACT 116-722.120(3) related to the
latter special evaluation, each of which is cited in this Inspection report.
The agency submitted five acceptable corrective action plans during this
reporting period.
The first corrective action plan was related to the agency’s 2022 Renewal inspection
where it received the following rule violations:
• R400.12212(2)(e)(i)(ii) Personnel records.
• R400.12212(2)(h) Personnel records.
• R400.12311(2) (e) Foster parent/agency agreement.
• R400.12324 (8) Reevaluation.
• R400.12405(5)(a)(b) Change of placement.
• R400.12413(1)(c) (i) Medical and dental care policy.
• R400.12413(1)(d) Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12418(2) (b) Development of service plans.
• ISEP MISACWIS (Commitment 22).
• ISEP 6.30 Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66).
• ISEP 6.33 Assessments and Service Plans.
• ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
• FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.

• FOM 722-6H Documentation of Contacts.
• FOM 722-8 Foster Care-Initial Service Plan- Supervisory Approval.
• ADM 300 Child Adoption Assessment Addendum.
• ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports.
The agency made some progress with some aspects of this corrective action plan
as illustrated during the records’ review and staff interviews. However, the agency
had 17 total violations during their 2022 inspection and 25 citations during this
inspection, 12 of which are repeat violations. In addition, the special investigation
noted below that led to the first provisional license is a repeat violation.
The second corrective action plan related to special investigation 2022C0201003
regarding a complaint received on 1/3/2022. The complaint alleged that the
agency did not provide a response on a case emergency from 12/27/2021 –
12/29/2021. During the special investigation the evidence revealed the agency had
an emergency system in place, but a faulty telephone system, which the agency
was aware of before the holiday season, preventing them from addressing the
emergency that arose. The agency was found in violation of R400.12403(2)(f) for
Policy and procedures related to unusual incidents. The agency submitted an
acceptable corrective action plan in March of 2022 that indicated the telephone
answering system had been repaired by the vendor, the answering message
system had been programmed to provide instructions to callers on how to contact a
supervisor in case of an emergency, and staff were made aware of the process.
This corrective action plan has been completed.
The third corrective action plan related to special investigation 2022C0420008
regarding a complaint received on 1/21/2022 alleging financial instability for the
agency. The agency was ultimately found in violation of R400.12202(a) for Policy
and procedures related to financial instability in October 2022. A recommendation
occurred was made to Modify the agency’s license to a first provisional license. The
agency submitted an acceptable corrective plan in March 2023. The corrective
action plan was approved in April 2023; and the agency was placed on a first
provisional license. The agency has made progress with various aspects of this
corrective action plan. This includes establishment of a finance committee so as to
provide financial recommendations to the board; establishment of a contract with
ADP for payroll, provider payments, so as to ensure for timely payments to staff and
caregivers; hiring of a new independent accounting firm (GJC); all of these action
steps have been verified. Additionally, the agency has settlement agreements with
the state related to three overpayment issues. Documentation showing the
agency’s pay off of one of these overpayment issues, and payments on the other
two overpayment issues, as agreed, was verified. The agency also has a payment
installment agreement with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) related to an old
debt. Payments to the IRS were to commence on 7/28/2023, via direct bank
withdrawal payments by the IRS. The IRS did not initiate these payments as they
had indicated. In October 2023 the agency initiated them. The agency provided
proof of that, and that it made the next higher payment amount as required by the
IRS in November and December 2023. As for an arrangement with the Department

related to another old debt for 2014 and 2015 payment advancements this remains
pending. With regards to the agency’s current financial standing, the agency
reported some gains. The agency hired two additional staff to work on increasing
placements (unfortunately one had resigned, but another was being hired). The
agency is also working with community friends to find way to bring in revenue.
The fourth corrective action plan related to special investigation 2022C000016
related to a complaint received on 5/5/2022. The complaint alleged confidential
information, regarding multiple individuals, many foster children serviced by the
agency, was breached. During the special investigation the evidence showed the
agency’s 2008 server was hacked and encrypted with ransomware and certain
children files were viewed or accessed. The agency was found in violation
R400.12213 (c) for Record management, related to storing and securing each
record for confidentiality and to prevent unauthorized access. The agency submitted
an acceptable corrective action plan in August 2022. The corrective action plan
indicated security awareness training for all staff; notification to all staff to report
suspicious activity to the office manager; IT consultant monitoring and reporting;
and reporting of any of suspicious breaches to the Department. Implementation and
completion of this corrective action plan was verified.
The fifth corrective action plan related to special investigation, 2022C0000231
related to a complaint received 2/8/2023. The complaint alleged that an agency
worker was made aware of alleged sexual maltreatment of a youth and the worker
never made a complaint to centralized intake. During the special investigation, the
agency worker admitted she did not report the allegation of sexual maltreatment as
required by the agency’s policy. The agency was found in violation of R400.1214 for
compliance with the child protection law. The agency submitted an acceptable
corrective plan in April 2023. This corrective action plan involved creation of an
emergency mandatory reporting protocol policy and indicated the policy would be
adhered to by workers during personal emergencies, and agency leaves; that
notification of the new policy would occur to all foster and adoptive families, and all
staff; and the policy would be discussed at unit staff meetings. This corrective
action plan has been completed.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted an annual chief administrator's report dated 8/28/2023. The
report was completed as required, and no concerns were noted.
Financial Overview
The agency provided a projected 2023 operational budget, and a copy of the last
independent financial audit for the 2020-2021 year. As for the 2020-2021 financial
audit, information in it was part of the basis for a special investigation in 2022, which
lead to the provisional license the agency is currently under.
The agency’s independent financial audit for 2022 due 9/30/2023 was pending at
the time of the agency’s renewal inspection. The agency had asked for and
received an extension from the state for submission of the independent financial

audit. The audit noted that the factors indicated raise substantial doubt about the
agency’s ability to continue. Additionally, it indicated the agency has created a new
finance committee, as well as a funds development committee to come up with
strategies to eliminate the agency’s debt. Additionally, that the agency is increasing
its service capacity through its foster care program to increase revenue. That with
these additional measures in place the agency plans to eliminate its debt and
generate revenue.
The agency continues to have a substantial debt and will require additional time to
show they can meet all of their financial responsibilities.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to speaking with the chief administrator and licensing and adoption
manager who serves as the agency’s licensee designee, I also spoke with the foster
care supervisor and licensing worker. I also interviewed a foster care/adoption
worker; an adoption worker and three adoptive parents.
With the exception of one parent expressing concern related to the agency
technology being antiquated, and the worker not always apprising them of the
status of the adoption; positive regards were reported for the agency by the other
adoptive parents and by the employees.
The agency does not have youths in independent living, so no youths were required
to be interviewed.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A tour of the agency's offices and records’ storage was conducted; no safety issues
or other concerns were observed.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The agency had one safety alerts this inspection.
Concern:
On 6/12/2023 phone contact was attempted with the relative caregiver by the
Division of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) Analyst. After phone and text messages
to the caregiver, which continued to 6/21/2023, did not result in a return contact from
the caregiver for a home visit, a safety alert was completed. The agency was
advised to make a home visit to the caregiver’s residence to verify the wellbeing of
the child and the safety of the home.
Resolution:
The agency completed a home visit on 6/26/2023. The worker observed the child,
verified the child’s well-being and conducted a tour of the home. A working smoke
alarm and carbon monoxide detector were observed, along with no observable
health, sanitation or safety hazards. The home had accessible egress windows, no
fire arms, running water; and medication and cleaning supplies were properly

stored. The agency provided photos of the fire alarm, carbon monoxide detector,
windows, and rooms of the home.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. The agency has also not achieved enough significant
progress on its financial instablity which stemmed the special investigation’s
(2022C0420008) corrective action that resulted in adverse action placing the agency
on a provision license. Due to these findings, the department recommends that the
agency’s license be modified to a second provisional license.
